topic.para: You can use the following troubleshooting tips to identify and resolve issues with &systemd; services and ensure a smooth system operation.

varlistentry.term: Check the syntax of your &systemd; unit file with the systemd-analyze verify SERVICE.

listitem.para: Before starting or enabling a &systemd; service, check the syntax of the unit file to ensure there are no errors. For example:
The command analyzes the unit file and reports any syntax errors, missing files, or other issues. You must fix any reported issues before enabling and starting the service.

varlistentry.term: Check the logs for your service with the journalctl -u SERVICE command.

listitem.para: If you experience any issue with a &systemd; service, check the service's log. For example:
The command displays logs for the specified service, including any error messages, warnings, or other relevant information. You can use these logs to identify and fix issues with the service.

varlistentry.term: Use the systemd-analyze plot command to visualize the boot process.

listitem.para: If a service is causing issues during the boot process, you can use the systemd-analyze plot command to visual the boot process and identify issues. For example:

The command creates a SVG file called boot-plot.svgthat contains a graphical representation of the boot process and the potential issues. This includes the start and stop time of each service. You can open this file in a SVG compatible image viewer or web browser to analyze services that are causing issues during the boot process.
